reviewText:
A fine logic puzzler with a rather reasonable price tag. The main gist of the game is to solve each problem as optimally as possible and see where you rank in the leaderboards in 3 different categories: objects used, overall beam length and the always important logic tics that it took to arrive to said solution.

Rather nice that the game allows you to save different solutions to the same puzzle and you can redo/undo all you want.

If this seems enjoyable to you than rest assured, it will be enjoyable. If not, then scamper off to play some other game more suited to your tastes. All good either way.

reviewText:
A great game for those who prefer a more relaxed, thought-provoking experience. It's very simple to begin with - just a few components and a tutorial - and becomes more and more diffucult as you progress through the levels, as you'd expect from any decent game.

However, I feel that the game has a rather steep learning curve (e.g. you aren't told that you can't place parts on dark tiles) and the logic gates aren't explained.

Overall though, a decent experience and definitely worth the investment!

reviewText: Prelogate is a puzzle game in which you attempt to direct a series of lasers to their designated output, while using logic design in order to be able to compensate for various combinations of inputs and expected outputs. Lasers can be one of three primary colors (red, blue, green), and outputs can be any combination of those outputs, allowing for a number of difficult scenarios.\n\nLasers are manipulated through the use of mirrors, mixers" which combine lasers
date: "splitters" which act as mirrors but also allow the laser through
recommended: "diffusers" which take input on every side and send out on every side
hoursPlayed: "prisms" which take white lasers and split them into the three primary colors
voteText: and logical AND
helpfulPercent: OR IF and XOR gates.\n\nIn addition to the general "find a solution" challenge
votesHelpful: there are a series of other challenges relating to number of items used
votesFunny: and whether or not you have any "dangling" lasers which don't connect to anything.\n\nThe UI can be a little cramped on lower resolutions
commentsCount: but there's a lot of variety in how to approach the problems (fully rotatable
column16: can be tuned into a top-down 2D view
column18: this is an excellent puzzle game which is well worth the asking price. Think of it as a game which is to logic design the same way Spacechem is to programming. I had to crack out K-maps for the first time since college

reviewText:
Prelogate is a puzzle game that will completely test your logic and solving skills. There are 64 levels in the game that will help you kill some time.
This is one of the most complex puzzle games I have ever played; and I'm having a hard time progressing through levels.

Gameplay: Solve puzzles by redirecting laser beams, mixing the beam colors, and controlling them with logic gates.
The game is quite simple, redirect the laser beam to the corresponding gate color.
It may sound easy but it's not.
It gets harder when you need to mix the colors of the laser beams to get  a specific beam color.
The game gets a lot more complex when they require you to set logic gates to perform a series of steps.

Graphics: The interface is simple and clean.
Very easy to understand.
The game offers 2D and 3D view in which you can switch anytime depending on your preference.

Audio: The background music is somewhat dull and repetitive.
Dull, but gives a calm ambiance.
It features elegant" type of music which fits the game.
The game has currently 8 background music
date:
Which randomly switches among the tracks while playing.
8 BGM that you will hear over and over again for 64 levels.

The tutorial is really handy.

The game is worth the price.
Though I suppose it could get a little lower.
If you're looking for a cheaper game: Yes
recommended:
there are puzzle games much cheaper than this.
It's up to you which one is worth purchasing.

Rating: 7.2/10

Disclaimer: Everything is purely based on my opinion.
Thanks for reading!~"

reviewText:
AbstractThis game is quite the mind bender. In fact, it bends your mind so much you may swear you can hear it screaming for you to stop. Prelogate is pretty much what it says on the main page; A game that uses lasers and mirrors to solve complex problems. The game itself is pretty straight-forward in that you just have to solve the puzzles. The music selection is slow and ambient, which is nice, but felt grating at some points. There's a...sorta plot, but at the same time its not entirely a plot. While the game itself is a challenge, it gets to a point where the challenge is excessive and one relies more on solution codes than spending 3 hours on one stage. While I would recommend it, it's not something I'd recommend to just anyone.

GameplayThe gameplay is, as said before, using lasers and mirrors. Cool, right? Who doesn't like using lasers for weird stuff? Unfortunately, the fun part wears off pretty quickly. The game starts with simple mirrors and lasers, relying on reflection and splitting to get to an endpoint. This lasts for a few levels before the game introduces logic gates; IF, OR, AND, XOR. Naturally, anyone with a smidge of computer science learning, or fumbling around in programming, knows what these are. So it's rather an unhappy moment when you realize these logic gates don't really...feel like they belong. Sure you know how they work because of the small text window, but that's all you get. You have to figure out how they work entirely in the levels they give it to you, because it does not get esaier after this point. It is here you realize the game is about to turn from difficulty curve into a full blown Kleiner's bottle of difficulty; no matter how hard you climb, you never really escape it. Solutions become downright maddening just to clear one step out of eight. Again, it is here you start to rely more on solution codes than actually working it out.

MusicIt's there, sure. It's pretty basic, nice space-like ambience to make you feel relaxed. Which doesn't help because this game needs you to fire all cylinders in your brain. Strange how that works.

PlotThe game has some...interesting mechanics outside of the actual game. However, these interesting mechanics are simply superficial; They're there to just sit there and look nice. You can interact with the pre-level UI in some ways, but it doesn't really do much. Can't explore who you are, why you're there, what kinda people are working with you. It's just for kicks. Part of me thinks it was going to be a part of something larger, but was scrapped for reasons unknown. While the over-arching plot is you making AI systems with lasers, I felt like there could've been a little more.

OverallI personally just could not enjoy the game after getting halfway through it. The logic gates really made the puzzles far more mind-bending than they deserved to be and the unfortunate reality to feel like I was too stupid to figure it out for myself, let alone for the rest of the game, really gave me a terrible taste in my mouth. The game does what it sets out to do, and does it well. That said, don't be surprised if you fall short of what the puzzles ask for and end up flailing hopelessly because you just don't entirely understand it. Thankfully, the pricetag is quite an enticing factor, so even if you don't really like it, 3$ for 64 levels of puzzles is a pretty rad deal.

I'm reluctantly recommending it on the off-chance people are masochistic and love a good challenge. Don't say I didn't warn you!

reviewText: I rather like this game.  The early levels are a bit easy but it's nice to have the opportunity to get to know each new part and use them several ways before the more complex and surprisingly difficult later levels.  Part of what I found really fun an interesting is that there are times that you must use simple gates to create more complex one.  Like, for instance, using xnor's to make other logic gates.  There is real world practicality in figuring out these problems, as these types of puzzles are at the heart of computer and electronics technology and some of the very same challenges faced in real-world engineering.  The relaxing motif and approachable presentation make it a rather fun diversion.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Exceptional programming puzzle game. Instead of finding a single solution, you build your very own solution. Later puzzles can get very tricky when you have limited space, but everything is solvable if you think and plan hard enough. After you have solved everything, you can optimize your solutions further to enhance certain aspects like f.e. the number of used devices. If you are competitive enough, you can add a lot of play time this way while climbing up the leaderboards, and I am far from done with 17 hours played.\n\nHowever, this game is not for everyone. You need a strong analytical mind to have fun here. If you enjoyed SpaceChem (you will most likely know that game if you belong to the target audience), you will enjoy this one as well.

reviewText:
I didn't know I wanted this until I saw it in the store and all the memories of old school laser-bouncing games came back...

DEFINITELY worth the <$4 cost. Worth more than that, honestly.

Redirect lasers to their endpoints, combine colors together, use gates and mixers and prisms to build logic games and solve multi-step puzzles.

The difficulty ramps up pretty severely but the game only gets more satisfying.

reviewText: If you are looking for a decent puzzle game that is similar to CHIP, this is the game to play. It is pretty simple at first glance, you simply need to get the matching colored laser into the proper receiver. The game throws a few twists along the way in terms of the structure changing mid puzzle to make this a  bit more interesting. I am only 8 levels in, but this will easily be worth the money if you are looking for a relaxing puzzle game to kill a few hours with.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A very solid logic puzzler. The difficulty curve can be a bit uneven across challenge sets but there are plenty of puzzles to keep you thinking and it continously introduces new puzzles or new ways of thinking to solve puzzles. It can get pretty darn hard too, though not quite as hard as some other pure-logic puzzles out there.

One thing I like about this game is that you can tell when your solutions work in advance, there's very little real trial-and-error. Though plenty of times where you fix a problem in one step only for a new problem to arise in a different step... but eventually with enough careful consideration the solution becomes clear.

The music is very nice and relaxing, I appreciated it. The presentation's a bit bare and the controls a bit iffy, and as well, there are a few small bugs, but nothing to detract too heavily from the well-crafted puzzles.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Prepare to melt your brain.

If you're not familiar with logic gates you want to make sure that you experiement and fully understand what differentiates them. Example:

IF gate will allow a beam to fire through it, if the gate is struck by a separate beam.

AND gates will fire a beam if both sides of it are hit by the same color (some exceptions with secondary colors)

OR gates will fire a beam if either side or both sides are struck by a separate beam.

XOR (exclusive or) gates will fire only if one side is being struck. So an OR will fire if both sides are being struck, an XOR will not.


Then you have to recreate these gates without them... some of those are particularly rough. Once you get past those 2-3 puzzles the difficulty drops back down to reasonably hard. Other than these quibbles with difficulty curve spike. this game is fantastic and will make your brain feel amazing when you complete puzzles.

Don't let the simplicity or low price tag fool you, this game is serious business. Definitely not for the average puzzle fan, this is some hardcore logic wiring puzzles.  Although at this price if you're even mildly interested you should buy it.

9/10  (ANY explanations of logic gates, and put those damn recreate a logic gate puzzles later in the game! Or last!)

reviewText:
+ Excellent puzzle/logic game manipilating light beams.
+ Starts simple and gets complicated quick.
+ Relaxing, soothing background music, a good wind down after a stressful day but the music can be turned off.

Details: Light transmiter devices must be routed to the correct light receiver devices.
~Mirror devices change beam directions.
~Simple splitter devices expand a single beam into multiple beams.
~Specialty splitter devices seperate a white beam into seperate color beams or the reverse.
~To achieve the highest scores use the least number of devices and the shortest beam lengths.
~But if this still sounds too easy, some levels require solutions for multiple steps in which the light transmiter devices send different colors or none at all and their counterpart light receiver devices require receiving different colors or none at all.
~Oh yeah, did I mention the logic gates?

reviewText:
Overall: Good to Very good
Difficulty: Can be medium-high

Likes:
- Puzzles are divided into steps.  In each step, a different subset of lasers / receivers are active, and laser beams must not hit inactive receivers.  Your solution must be valid for all steps simultaneously.  This is an innovative take on laser puzzle games that is interesting and challenging.
- There are 10 sets of puzzles, and almost every set of puzzles is based on a different theme and plays differently
- Can be quite challenging
- For additional challenge, you can make your solution clean" (laser beams don't go off the screen or hit obstacles).  You can also optimize your solution to minimize the number of devices used; the total length of the laser beams; or the number of devices plus the number of separate beams.  See comment below.

Dislikes:
- UI is clumsy.  If you click Play
date: you can't navigate to previous solved levels (need to click Level instead).  If you click Level
recommended: you can't proceed to the current unsolved level (need to click Play instead).  No quick puzzle reset (need to escape to menu).  Some pieces are hard to visually distinguish (e.g. mixers and diffusers).  Visually unclear in 2D view (e.g.
hoursPlayed: raised walls are nearly invisible).  Always need to rotate camera when starting a puzzle.\n- Every puzzle is progress locked\n- For the Obstacle and Platform sets of levels

- The optimization aspect of the game is reminiscent of SpaceChem

reviewText:
Oh, look! A puzzle game that actually makes me feel stupid!

Seriously, though, the puzzles are fairly balanced. You'll never feel like it's the game's fault for being a bit unintuitive. The only problem I DO have with it is that there's no way to cap the FPS, so the game will constantly run at 800 FPS even on a low end machine, which can wear your computer out in excess.

Great game, I'd recommend it.

reviewText: This was just a game I bought due to curiosity. Having played it for a little while its one of those games that gets under your skin a bit, there are no enemies or action involed just a series of ever more complex puzzles to push your thinking skills a little bit more each time.\nThe game involves placing mirrors, beam splitters, prisms and logic gates over the playing area in order to connect light emitters to their appropriate recievers by mixing (to get different colours) and diverting the beams of light, all of which is made harder by multi stage levels in which different emitters and recievers are switched on and off.\nMinor gripes are with the control system which can feel a little awkward and the clarity of the objectives during the tutorial but overall this is a fun and challenging game and one I would definately reccomend.
